message_1: A twin who is traveling in a spaceship at high speed returns to Earth to find that their twin sibling who stayed on Earth has aged more than they have. Calculate the age difference between the twins if one twin traveled at 0.8c (80% of the speed of light) for 5 years according to the twin paradox.
message_2:
To calculate the age difference between the twins, we need to use the time dilation formula from the theory of special relativity:

Δt' = Δt / √(1 - v²/c²)

where:
Δt' is the time experienced by the traveling twin (the proper time)
Δt is the time experienced by the twin on Earth (the coordinate time)
v is the speed of the traveling twin (0.8c)
c is the speed of light

First, we need to find the time dilation factor:

√(1 - v²/c²) = √(1 - (0.8c)²/c²) = √(1 - 0.64) = √(0.36) = 0.6

Now, we can find the proper time experienced by the traveling twin:

Δt' = Δt / 0.6

Since the twin on Earth experienced 5 years:

Δt' = 5 years / 0.6 ≈ 8.33 years

The traveling twin experienced approximately 8.33 years. The age difference between the twins is:

Age difference = 8.33 years - 5 years = 3.33 years

So, the twin who stayed on Earth aged 3.33 years more than the twin who traveled at 0.8c.
